body.p: The time it takes a surgeon to complete a laproscopic surgery to remove the gall bladder is normally distributed with a mean of 132.4 minutes and a standard deviation of 15.7 minutes. A patient’s risk of complications is increased the longer he is in surgery. An unusually risky surgery is one that is in the top 4% of all surgery lengths.
What is the minimum surgery length (in minutes) that would be considered unusually risky? Note: Answers are rounded to 1 decimal place.

response.feedback: Correct. In order to be in the top 4% of surgery times, a surgery must be 1.75 standard deviations above the mean. The surgery time is calculated as x = 1.75 * 15.7 + 132.4 = 159.9 minutes (rounded)
Incorrect. It looks like you calculated using the wrong z-score (−1.75 instead of 1.75). You want the z-score that corresponds to the top 4% of all surgery lengths.
Incorrect. It looks like you used the probability 0.9599 in your calculation. Remember, we need to find the z-score that corresponds to the probability to calculate x = z * SD + mean.
Incorrect. It looks like you switched values by using 15.7 for the mean and 132.4 for the standard deviation.

body.p: The lifetime in miles for a certain brand of tire is normally distributed with a mean of 22,000 miles and a standard deviation of 3,100 miles The tire manufacturer wants to offer a money-back guarantee so that no more than 3% of tires will qualify for a refund. What is the minimum number of miles the manufacturer should guarantee that the tires will last?

response.feedback: Correct. In order to be in the bottom 3% of tire lifetimes a tire must be 1.88 standard deviations below the mean (z = −1.88). The mileage is calculated as x = −1.88 * 3,100 + 22,000 = 16,172.
